liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Emilie Gramenz in Washington DC As Trump’s motorcade left the Miami courthouse, throngs of supporters waving signs and cheering lined the streets. There were no barriers separating them from the road. CNN had a live shot of what appeared to be Trump waving and giving a double thumbs up through the dark tinted windows of an SUV - when seconds later Secret Service officers could be seen scrambling. One protester had lunged towards the motorcade. He was quickly dragged away and cameras captured him sitting on the footpath surrounded by police.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Trump has left court with two thumbs up

children.content: Reporting by Emilie Gramenz in Washington DC
As Trump’s motorcade left the Miami courthouse, throngs of supporters waving signs and cheering lined the streets.
There were no barriers separating them from the road.
CNN had a live shot of what appeared to be Trump waving and giving a double thumbs up through the dark tinted windows of an SUV - when seconds later Secret Service officers could be seen scrambling.
One protester had lunged towards the motorcade.
He was quickly dragged away and cameras captured him sitting on the footpath surrounded by police.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Trump has been allowed to leave court without conditions or travel restrictions. No cash bond was required. Judge Jonathan Goodman ruled that Trump was not allowed to communicate with potential witnesses in the case, according to CNN. Here are some photos from when Trump arrived at the courthouse earlier today.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: No bond or travel restrictions

children.content: Trump has been allowed to leave court without conditions or travel restrictions.
No cash bond was required.
Judge Jonathan Goodman ruled that Trump was not allowed to communicate with potential witnesses in the case, according to CNN.
Here are some photos from when Trump arrived at the courthouse earlier today.

props.alt: A man in a striped, prison uniform holding a placard stands in front of the Trump motorcade. Two security officers are walking towards him.

children.content: Donald Trump's motorcade arrives.
(Reuters: Greg Lovett)
A supporter of Donald Trump and an anti-Trump demonstrator argue near the courthouse.
(Reuters: Marco Bello)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Crisis support centres will remain open in the New South Wales Hunter Valley region for the next week, in the wake of Sunday night's bus crash which claimed 10 lives. Drop-in clinics will be open from: 9am at the Singleton Youth Venue 10am at the Branxton Community Centre The identities of the victims have become publicly known, with most of them from the Singleton area. NSW Premier Chris Minns will return to the region this morning and is expected to announce further support for those impacted by the tragedy. Emergency service personel are also coming to terms with what they witnessed. The bus driver, Brett Button, faced court yesterday on dangerous and negligent driving charges, and was granted bail .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Crisis centres open as community comes to grips with deadly bus crash

props.alt: Two police stand near an overturned bus on the side of a road

children.content: (AAP: Darren Pateman)
Crisis support centres will
remain open in the New South Wales Hunter Valley region for the next week
, in the wake of Sunday night's bus crash which claimed 10 lives.
Drop-in clinics will be open from:
9am at the Singleton Youth Venue
10am at the Branxton Community Centre
The identities of the victims have become publicly known, with most of them from the Singleton area.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Nick Kyrgios has lost on his comeback from knee surgery 7-5, 6-3 to Chinese player Wu Yibing in the first round of the Stuttgart Open. Kyrgios, a 2022 Wimbledon finalist and two-time semifinalist in Stuttgart, was playing for the first time since October in Tokyo. The 28-year-old Australian had a knee operation in January. On Twitter, Kyrgios wrote: "Be patient with me my fans please…. It’s a process to get back to where I was. "I know it’s hard for you to see me perform like today, but I need more time and hopefully can get back to where I was." Wu, who was playing his first professional match on grass, next faces Marton Fucsovics, who rallied to beat Denis Shapovalov 3-6, 6-3, 6-4.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Be patient with me': Nick Kyrgios loses comeback match after knee surgery

props.alt: Composite of two photos: Australian tennis player Nick Kyrgios hits a ball, and China's Wu Yibing clenches his fist

children.content: (AP: Marijan Murat/dpa)
Nick Kyrgios has lost on his comeback from knee surgery
7-5, 6-3 to Chinese player Wu Yibing
in the first round of the Stuttgart Open.
Kyrgios, a 2022 Wimbledon finalist and two-time semifinalist in Stuttgart, was playing for the first time since October in Tokyo.
The 28-year-old Australian had a knee operation in January.
On Twitter, Kyrgios wrote:
"Be patient with me my fans please…. It’s a process to get back to where I was.
"I know it’s hard for you to see me perform like today, but I need more time and hopefully can get back to where I was."
Wu, who was playing his first professional match on grass, next faces Marton Fucsovics, who rallied to beat Denis Shapovalov 3-6, 6-3, 6-4.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Yesterday afternoon the Denver Nuggets claimed their first NBA title, after taking down the Miami Heat 4-1 in the finals series. Nuggets centre Nikola Jokić guided Denver to championship victory, as the Nuggets overcame dreadful shooting and a late flurry from Miami's Jimmy Butler to squeeze past the Heat for a frantic 94-89 comeback victory in Game Five. The celebrations rolled on into the night, with Jokić dunking his teammate Jamal Murray into a swimming pool.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: News Australia is searching for: NBA Finals

props.alt: A top-down photo of a white basketballer shoots a layup  near other opposing players

children.content: Denver centre Nikola Jokić was crowned the Finals MVP.
(AP: Jack Dempsey)
Yesterday afternoon the Denver Nuggets claimed their first NBA title, after
taking down the Miami Heat 4-1
in the finals series.
Nuggets centre Nikola Jokić guided Denver to championship victory, as the Nuggets overcame dreadful shooting and a late flurry from Miami's Jimmy Butler to squeeze past the Heat for
a frantic 94-89 comeback victory
in Game Five.
The celebrations rolled on into the night, with Jokić dunking his teammate Jamal Murray into a swimming pool.

image.altText: A pile of US bank notes

items.synopsis: Investor optimism that the Federal Reserve will keep rates on hold this week drives stocks higher. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: US interest rate pause expected as inflation slows, ASX eyes gains

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning! Stephanie Chalmers here to take you through the day ahead on markets. And we've had a pretty good lead from overseas to get us started — ASX futures are higher after the S & P 500 hit a fresh 13-month high on Wall Street. The reason for the optimism? The latest US consumer price index showed the smallest annual increase in inflation in more than two years in May. The news comes as the Federal Reserve kicks off its two-day meeting, with a decision on interest rates due tomorrow morning, our time. According to Refinitiv, market pricing puts the odds of no change to US rates tomorrow at 93 per cent. "A cooling inflation report is fueling this bull market as the Fed should have no problem skipping a rate hike," OANDA senior market analyst Edward Moya wrote in a note. "Wall Street is becoming a little bit hopeful here that an FOMC June skip could eventually become a July pause." So stick with us through the day to see how this all plays out.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Investor optimism over slowing US inflation boosts markets

children.content: Good morning!
Stephanie Chalmers
here to take you through the day ahead on markets.
And we've had a pretty good lead from overseas to get us started — ASX futures are higher after
the S
P 500 hit a fresh 13-month high
on Wall Street.
The reason for the optimism? The latest US consumer price index showed
the smallest annual increase in inflation in more than two years
in May.
The news comes as the Federal Reserve kicks off its two-day meeting, with a decision on interest rates due tomorrow morning, our time.
According to Refinitiv,
market pricing puts the odds of no change to US rates tomorrow at 93 per cent
"A cooling inflation report is fueling this bull market as the Fed should have no problem skipping a rate hike," OANDA senior market analyst Edward Moya wrote in a note.
"Wall Street is becoming a little bit hopeful here that an FOMC June skip could eventually become a July pause."
So stick with us through the day to see how this all plays out.
